metadata.bible_text: Ruth 4:14 (and the book of Ruth as a whole)
metadata.sermon_start_end: If we were Jewish, we would be reading all four chapters of the book of Ruth today, as Jews do every year at Shabuot (the Feast of Weeks). The Episcopal lectionary, by contrast, is very stingy with Ruth. All we get to hear is the first half of [...] The foreign maiden was the ancestor of Jesus. The story of Ruth, Naomi, and Boaz finds its fulfillment in the only begotten Son of God, who made himself to be next-of-kin for the entire human race, the Redeemer of the whole world. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon attempts to cover the entire book of Ruth rather than a specific pericope. Dekker warns that a sermon on a 'biblical character' or a general 'short story' is not a sermon. It fails to identify what is in this text that can be found NOWHERE else; instead, it treats the text as a moral illustration of general divine kindness.
quotes: It may be a mistake to try to encompass the story of Ruth in the space of one sermon, but we are going to take a shot at it
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus exclusively on one chapter or even a few verses (e.g., the threshing floor scene) to extract the unique theological 'point' that is absent from the rest of Scripture.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates knowledge of the original context, specifically the concept of the 'go’el' (redeemer) and the sociological vulnerability of widows. However, the exegesis remains at the level of narrative retelling rather than deep theological exposition of the Hebrew text's nuances.
quotes: The Hebrew word 'next-of-kin' (goʾel) is the same as the word 'redeemer.'
In that ancient culture, nothing could have been worse. Naomi, in fact, says a terrible thing
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond narrative summary into the 'theology of the biblical books' as Dekker requires, specifically exploring the tension of the Moabite inclusion in the assembly of Israel.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is somewhat concrete (mentioning the Taliban or modern famines), but it quickly devolves into 'general truths' which Dekker explicitly forbids. The idea that 'when you reach out your hand, it is the hand of God' is a general moralism rather than a specific application of the Ruth-Boaz dynamic to the contemporary hearer's spiritual life.
quotes: When you reach out your hand to another, it is the hand of God. When you are faithful to your spouse, it is the faithfulness of God.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid turning the text into a series of 'general truths' about kindness. Apply the specific 'stranger' status of Ruth to the congregation's specific cultural context.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'running commentary' style. It retells the story and pauses for brief 'lessons.' This is not the 'mixed' movement Dekker describes where the hearer is 'expounded' together with the text. The application feels tacked onto the narrative segments.
quotes: Now we meet Boaz. Our first glimpse of him is delightful.
The world is indeed full of famine... The story of Ruth shows us in an incomparable way...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Structure the sermon so that the contemporary situation is viewed through the lens of the text from the start, rather than summarizing the story first.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The category of 'misery' is well-articulated through Naomi's bitterness and the reality of death/famine. 'Redemption' is present via Boaz. However, the 'gratitude' part is flattened into general human kindness rather than a specific response to God's grace.
quotes: Naomi feels that she has been abandoned by God. No, it is even worse than that. She feels that God is actively against her.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' from physical famine to the spiritual 'lostness' before God that Dekker emphasizes.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon almost entirely avoids the 'two ways.' While it mentions 'alternatives' for Ruth and Boaz, it lacks the gravity of being 'lost in time or eternity.' It presents the choices as 'wonderful opportunities' rather than matters of life and death/destruction.
quotes: Ruth did not need to go with Naomi; it was not an obligation laid upon her. It was something very much more wonderful
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the consequence of the 'broad way.' What would it mean for Ruth to remain with the gods of Moab? The seriousness of the choice must be sharpened.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned at the very end as a 'fulfillment' and the 'ancestor.' However, Christ is not the 'telos' that drives the entire sermon. The sermon is more about human kindness being 'incarnate' in Boaz than about the unique work of the God-Man.
quotes: The story of Ruth... finds its fulfillment in the only begotten Son of God... the Redeemer of the whole world.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the doctrine of the two natures and Christ's unique role as Redeemer is the goal (telos) of the sermon, not just a concluding genealogical note.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18.5 minutes, the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. This lack of 'breadth' results in a narrative summary rather than a deep theological 'boring' into the text.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the depth of theological reflection on the specific text to reach the 20-minute threshold, avoiding the 'stingy' approach of the lectionary by providing substantive 'breadth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily because it attempts to cover too much ground (the whole book) and consequently settles for general moral truths. It functions more as a narrative retelling with ethical lessons than a 'recreation of the Bible into a new, current, proclamatory word.' The 'two ways' are absent, and the Christology is appended rather than central.
strengths: Adequate identification of the 'misery' in Naomi's situation.
Clear explanation of the 'go'el' concept in its original context.
weaknesses: Violation of Thesis 1.3: Treating a whole book/character rather than a specific passage.
Violation of Thesis 3: Reliance on 'general truths' about kindness.
Violation of Thesis 6: Lack of the 'seriousness of choice' or the possibility of being lost.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a narrative lecture with moral applications, but it is not a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the specific focus, the interwoven urgency, and the 'two ways' necessary for true proclamation.
